itemDescription: Welsh rugby union and rugby league footballer

wikipedia_page.main: Harold "Hal" James Jones (22 December 1907 – 16 October 1955) was a Welsh rugby union, and professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1920s and 1930s. He played representative level rugby union (RU) for Wales, and at club level for Neath RFC, Maesteg RFC, Cardiff RFC, Glamorgan Police RFC and Glamorgan County RFC, as a lock, i.e. number 4 or 5, and representative level rugby league (RL) for Wales, and at club level for Wigan and Keighley as a prop, or second-row, i.e. number 8 or 10, or, 11 or 12, during the era of contested scrums.

response: * Harold Jones (artist) (1904–1992), British artist, illustrator and author of children's books
* Harold Jones (rugby) (1907–1955), rugby union and rugby league footballer of the 1920s and 1930s
* Harold Jones (drummer) (born 1940), known for his work with other jazz musicians such as Count Basie
* Griffith Jones (actor) (Harold Jones, 1909–2007), British stage and television actor
*Harold Jones (bishop), American prelate of the Episcopal Church
